questions.text: Spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called  _____
questions.solution:
Spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called receptive field.

Sensory Unit: A single afferent neuron with all its receptor endings.

Motor unit: Each single motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates.

Dermatome: Each spinal nerve innervates a “segmental field” of the skin.

questions.text: Fast vibration sense is mediated by ______.
questions.solution:
Fast vibration sense is mediated by Pacinian corpuscles. 

Pacinian corpuscle is the most sensitive mechanoreceptor in the somatosensory system. It is responsive to high-frequency (30–500 Hz) vibratory stimuli and pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors.

Option A: Merkel's disc sense touch and sustained pressure. They are slow adapting receptors. Present in epidermis.

Option B: Meissner's corpuscle sense tap and flutter. They are present in dermal papillae. They are rapidly adapting receptors. 

Option D: Ruffini endings sense skin stretch and fluttering vibration.

The following image shows Merkel's disc and Meissner's corpuscle being more superficial (reponsive to touch) than Ruffini endings and Pacinian corpuscle (which are deeper in the dermis and responsive to pressure).

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: The phasic receptor is______
questions.solution:
Meissner's corpuscles are phasic (rapidly adapting) receptors.

Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, and muscle spindle are tonic (slowly adapting) receptors.

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: You are doing a CNS examination of a patient with a spinal injury. At which of the following sites would the distance of two-point discrimination be greatest?
questions.solution:
The distance of two-point discrimination is greatest at the back of the scapula. 

The relative tactile acuity of a given region can be determined by the two-point discrimination test. Here, calipers are used to determine the minimum distance between the two points which can be perceived as two points. Greater the density of receptors → Smaller the receptive field → More precise the localization.

For e.g., Stimulus points on the back, for instance, must be separated by at least 65 mm before they can be distinguished as separate, whereas on the fingertips two stimuli are recognized if they are separated by as little as 2 mm. The lips have the greatest acuity (two-point discrimination threshold ~ 1 mm).

Clinical significance: 

Blind individuals benefit from the tactile acuity of fingertips to facilitate the ability to read Braille. The dots forming Braille symbols are separated by 2.5 mm. 

Two-point discrimination is used to test the integrity of the dorsal column (medial lemniscus) system.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about  the nature of the sensory receptor given below:
questions.solution:
The sensory receptor shown in the above image is Pacinian corpuscle. The Pacinian corpuscle is a rapidly adapting receptor and is an encapsulated receptor.

When a stimulus of the same strength is continuously given to a sensory receptor, the frequency of the action potentials generated by the receptor gradually decreases. This phenomenon is known as receptor adaptation. Depending on whether the receptor stops responding to a stimulus rapidly or slowly, they are classified as rapidly adapting (phasic) or slow adapting receptors (tonic).

questions.text: Which of the following classification of receptors is the same?
questions.solution:
Mechanoreceptors and exteroceptors have the same classification of receptors. 

Exteroceptors are concerned with the external environment or receptors which receives external stimuli. Mechanoreceptors are cutaneous receptors for touch and pressure. Thus mechanoreceptors can be considered to be exteroceptors. 

Nociceptors are pain receptors which detect physical and chemical damage occuring in the tissue. 

Interoceptors are concerned with the internal environment.

Chemoreceptors are receptors stimulated by a change in the chemical composition of the environment in which they are located. These include receptors for taste and smell as well as visceral receptors such as those sensitive to changes in the plasma level of O2, pH, and osmolality.

Teleceptors (distance receivers) are concerned with events at a distance, example - photoreceptors.

Proprioceptors provide information about the position of the body in space at any given instant.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding sensory receptor properties?

choices.text: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the intensity of the stimulus
A touch receptor will generate a constant rate of discharge of its axon for as long as the receptor is stimulated
Meissner’s and Pacinian corpuscles adapt slowly, the others adapt rapidly
The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the stimulus given to its receptor

questions.solution:
The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the stimulus given to its receptor.

Intensity of stimulus applied to a sensory receptor can be determined by the following:

  • Variation in frequency of action potentials generated 
  • Variations in the number of receptors activated 

Option A : Weber-Fechner Law states that magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.

Option B: A touch receptor will not generate a constant rate of discharge, even if the receptor is continuously stimulated. This is called desensitization or adaptation. If the opposite were true (if option B was correct), when we have our clothes on, we would have constant firing of neurons unnecessarily, in response to touch stimulus.

Option C:

Slow adapting (Tonic receptors)  Rapidly adapting (Phasic receptors) 
Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs   Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: Aδ fibers do not transmit _____.
questions.solution:
Aδ fibers do not transmit slow pain. They transmit fast pain. 

Activation of Aδ fibers, which release glutamate, is responsible for first pain (also called fast pain or epicritic pain), which is a rapid response and mediates the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus.

Neuropathic pain can also be burning, dull and poorly localized (protopathic pain, transmitted by C nociceptor fibers (which release substance P). 

Dual Pain Pathway

Pain can be carried by either Aδ fiber (fast pain/ epicritic pain) or by C fiber (slow pain/protopathic pain)

questions.text: The most potent algogenic  substance is ______.
questions.solution:
Bradykinin is the most potent algogenic substance.

An algogenic substance is a chemical released at the site of injury which mediates pain. These include bradykinin, serotonin, histamine, potassium ions, acids, acetylcholine, and proteolytic enzymes.

Prostaglandins and substance P enhance the sensitivity of pain endings but do not directly excite them.

Note: This is a controversial question

According to Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page 622-

"One chemical that seems to be more painful than others is bradykinin. Researchers have suggested that bradykinin might be the agent most responsible for causing pain after tissue damage."

Hence, bradykinin is the better answer (not serotonin)

questions.text: Vanilloid receptors are activated by all except ______.
questions.solution:
Vanilloid receptors are not activated by vibration.

Vanilloid receptors or TRPV1 (transient receptor potential vanilloid1) receptors are a part of family of nonselective cation channels called transient receptor potential (TRP) channels. These channels respond to intense heat, acids, and chemicals such as capsaicin.

questions.text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to  ____.
questions.solution:
Weber-Fechner Law states that the magnitude of sensation felt is proportionate to the log of the intensity of the stimulus.

Other Laws in Physiology:

  • Doctrine of specific nerve energies - When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated.
  • Law of projection - No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor. This principle is called the law of projection.

questions.text: A patient's right leg was amputated because it was unsalvageable after the motor vehicle accident. After 2 weeks of her surgery, she started feeling episodes of severe pain in the amputated area. This pain is most likely based on which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
This patient is having phantom limb pain. This pain is based on cortical plasticity.

Cortical structures are capable of reorganization after the loss of a body part. The cortical representation of the neighboring parts spreads into the cortical area that was formerly occupied by the representation of the amputated part. This is called cortical plasticity leads to the phenomenon of phantom limb pain

questions.text: Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is ________
questions.solution:
Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is allodynia.

Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus. An example of primary hyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which results from sensitization of the skin pain endings by local tissue products released due to burns — histamine, prostaglandins, and others.

Causalgia is a type of neuropathic pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anandamide?

choices.text: There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray

questions.solution:
There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray and other areas concerned with pain.

There are 2 types of endogenous cannabinoids: 2-arachidonyl glycerol and Anandamide. They bind to CB1 and CB2 receptors. They have an anti-nociceptive effect.

Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiates.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about visceral pain?

choices.text: It is mediated by B fibers

questions.solution:
Visceral pain is poorly localized, unpleasant and associated with nausea and autonomic symptoms. It often originates from thoracic and abdominal cavities, transmitted through small type C pain fibers. 

It often radiates (or is referred) to other somatic structures perhaps due to convergence of somatic and visceral nociceptive afferent fibers on the same second-order neurons in the spinal dorsal horn that project to the thalamus and then to the primary somatosensory cortex.

When pain is referred, it is usually to a structure that developed from the same embryonic segment or dermatome as the structure in which the pain originates. This principle is called the dermatomal rule. 

Example: the heart and the arm have the same segmental origin.

questions.text: Pain insensitive structure is _____.
questions.solution:
Alveoli are pain insensitive structures. Alveoli of lungs and parenchyma of liver are almost completely insensitive to the pain of any type.

However, the liver capsule is extremely sensitive to both direct trauma and stretch. The bile ducts, arterial walls, bronchi and the parietal pleura are very sensitive to pain.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pain is undergoing transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation for pain relief. What is the basis of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) of pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury to relieve pain. 

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

The relief may result from inhibition of pain pathways (Inhibition of C fibers and A-delta fibers) in the dorsal horn gate, by stimulation of large-diameter touch-pressure afferents(A-beta fibers). This is called the gate-control hypothesis.

Interesting clinical application: Touching or shaking an injured area decreases the pain due to the injury. Stimulation with an electric vibrator at the site of pain also gives some relief.

The same mechanism is probably responsible for the efficacy of counterirritants. Stimulation of the skin over an area of visceral inflammation produces some relief of the pain due to the visceral disease. The old-fashioned mustard plaster works on this principle.

questions.text: Primary cutaneous hyperalgesia_____

choices.text: Develops in the normal skin region around the area of flare
Is an abnormal condition in the skin in which painful stimuli become less severe
Is due to changes in threshold of pain receptors
Is associated with throbbing type of pain

questions.solution:
Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus.

  • Hyperalgesia and allodynia signify increased sensitivity of nociceptive afferent fibers.
  • Causes of hyperalgesia
    • The excessive sensitivity of the pain receptors, which is called primary hyperalgesia
    • Facilitation of sensory transmission, which is called secondary hyperalgesia. 

An example of primary hyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which results from sensitization of the skin pain endings, by local tissue products from the burn — histamine, prostaglandins, and others.

Secondary hyperalgesia frequently results from lesions in the spinal cord or the thalamus.

questions.text: The transient receptor potential (TRP) channel that is most active at normal skin temperature is _______.
questions.solution: At normal skin temperatures, TRPV3 is the most active receptor.

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario rectal temperature would be the preferred site to measure the core body temperature.

During low or high temperatures like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperatures

Infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is representative of core body temperature. However, more often the thermometer is not inserted adequately or for safety reasons, they are manufactured in such a way that they do not reach deep into the ear canal, or the ear canal contains cerumen which can disturb the measurement. Hence the infrared thermometer more commonly delivers the temperature of ear canal cerumen and hence not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature.
